name: Set of four Hvidt & Molgaard Nielsen teak side chairs for Soborg Mobelfabrik
description:
Set of four Hvidt & Molgaard Nielsen teak side chairs for Soborg Mobelfabrik Denmark circa 1950s.

Super quality chairs, obviously influenced by their contemporary Finn Juhl's work. 
The design cleverly incorporates bent laminated plywood which is faced in a beautiful teak wood veneer to form the curved back element. There's also a detailed biscuit joint to the centre of the back rail, again this is  picking up on another of their contemporaries work (Hans Wegner).
Normally seen with a rush/paper cord seat, these examples have their original cloth seats (green/blue colour). Unfortunately the foam has deteriorated, so they will need new foam/upholstery, (would look stunning in black/brown leather.

Condition : as stated will need recovering etc, the frame and seat backs are in excellent order just having been cleaned and oiled.

name: Stunning vintage Hans Wegner teak & cane sofa/daybed for Getama Denmark c1957
description:
For sale we have a stunning vintage Hans Wegner designed teak and rattan cane sofa/daybed and produced circa 1957 by Getama Denmark.

In my opinion this early example is the by far the best sofa/daybed Hans Wegner ever designed. The combination of natural materials and clean uncluttered lines are unsurpassed by the later versions which use cheaper materials/construction.

The clever part of its design, is the angled rattan cane back element, its intention is that during the day it can be used for pillow/blanket storage and at night you simply lift the hinged mechanism and the back raises and shuts flat to reveal all the mattress for sleeping.

This piece comes with an interesting provenance. The sofa/daybed which along with other interesting period items I am listing for sale, comes from the deceased estate of the British 'Brutalist' architect Rodney Gordon. He is most famous for the Michael Faraday Memorial in the center of the Elephant & Castle roundabout.
He also designed the Trinity Centre, Gateshead, which became known to a wider audience as the carpark from whose roof mobster Jack Carter (Michael Caine) threw the corrupt councillor Cliff Brumby (Bryan Mosley) in the 1971 cult film Get Carter. Loved and loathed, but never unnoticed, Gordon's audacious designs marked him out as a seminal figure in English brutalist architecture.

This beautiful and rare piece has been lovingly and sympathetically restored by an incredible team of craftsman/women over the last three months. The list of work done includes : the teak elements stripped and re-polished, the beech/pine frame stripped and re-polished (thank you Max) the rattan cane replaced (each piece woven by hand, which is an incredibly difficult job to do, again thank you Francis for all your hard work) the original wire underframe mattress cleaned and re-sprung then covered, top mattress re-foamed (to pass fire regulations) then recovered in a gorgeous 100% wool tartan/plaid (cost £65 per metre plus upholstery fee, thanks Ian) all original hardware kept and re-used including hinges, screws etc, 

Measurements: length 200 cm, depth 86 cm, seat height 40 cm, mattress size 193 cm x 86 cm

To summarise : when the sofa/daybed first came into our possession it was in pretty poor condition. unfortunately it had been neglected over the years, the frame had various marks/scuffs, the cane had perished and the mattress was thread bare. 

We looked upon it as a labour of love, just like restoring an old house or classic car. we quickly realised that it was going to take lots of time and money to put it back into as near its original factory condition. But we wanted to see the project through and save a classic piece of Danish mid-centry design from the scrap heap, after all this was designed by one of the 20th centuries leading furniture makers and I'd like to think we've succeeded and done a good job.

We are offering it for sale at a buy it now price of £1650 or best offer, which I think is a fair price considering the time, effort and money that's been invested in it. And also the fact that you're buying a piece of furniture design history, for the comparable price of  a new sofa from the likes of Conran or Heals etc.

Any Questions please message me at dad-design@hotmail.co.uk or 07940458890, viewing is available most times/days. Pick up from our home address in London SE19 preferred.

This piece along with other interesting period items comes from the deceased estate of the British 'Brutalist' architect Rodney Gordon, who is famous for the Michael Faraday Memorial in the center of the Elephant & Castle roundabout.
He also designed the Trinity Centre, Gateshead, which became known to a wider audience as the carpark from whose roof mobster Jack Carter (Michael Caine) threw the corrupt councillor Cliff Brumby (Bryan Mosley) in the 1971 cult film Get Carter. Loved and loathed, but never unnoticed, Gordon's audacious designs marked him out as a seminal figure in English brutalist architecture.

name: Vintage 'Cantilever 41555 Mark II' desk light by Gerald Abramovitz for Best & Lloyd (GB) circa 1966
description:
Vintage 'Cantilever 41555 Mark II' desk light by Gerald Abramovitz for Best & Lloyd (GB) circa 1966.

Made from self coloured anodised aluminium with a black steel base.

The late Gerald Abramovitz was a South African born architect and industrial designer who studied at the Royal College of Art in London. 

The desk light's form projects a remarkable forward-looking, minimalist aesthetic for a 1961 design. After deliberating with the company a few changes were made and this model the mark 11 was produced circa 1963.

The lamp won a coveted Design Centre Award in 1966 and was included in the landmark exhibition 'Design Since 1945' held at the Philadelphia Museum of Art in 1983-1984.

He subsequently designed furniture for Knoll and Hille.
 
Another copy of this lamp is held in the collection of the Museum of Modern art in New York
 
The lamp is in excellent working order with minimal wear/marking.
 
Measures : 20 x 27 1/2 x 3 5/8" or (50.8 x 69.8 x 9.2 cm).

To be honest I can't get the thing to open to check whats inside it!....it turns as to grind something, but I can't get it to open and I'm afraid to apply too much force in case I damage it.

If any kind soul recognizes this particular model and feels generous enough to offer some info it would be greatly appreciated.

As you can see from the photographs its very modern/contemporary and stylish in its design which you can put down to Georg Jensen's son Soren was primarily a sculptor and therefore interested in form etc.

It has a full set of marks to the underside which includes : Georg Jensen, Denmark, Sterling, Dessin, and SGJ initials.

All the foam has been replaced with new, the sofa itself has been recovered using a lovely cotton/wool mix material in a shade of dove grey. The wooden frame and legs/feet have been stripped and polished/waxed etc.

name: Vintage Robin Day 'Plus' Group modular seating units for Hille circa 1965
description:
Vintage Robin Day 'Plus' Group modular seating units for Hille circa 1965.

The 'Plus' group system was designed by Day in 1965 to follow on from the 'Form' group series of 1960. 

It incorporates a solid African walnut wooden rectilinear frame in which upholstered seating and table units cleverly slot into place allowing different seating combinations to be used.

The Plus group has prominent exposed combed joints to the corners, which not only provided extra strength, but also heighlighted its honest construction and rectilinear form which had become fashionable during this period.

This set comprises : two free-standing African walnut frames, five seating units (two with arm ends) and one upholstered table/seat.
As stated earlier, this set can be changed around ie you could have a three seater with arms at each end and a two seater open sofa with end seat.....or a five seater sofa with end seat etc.

As you can see from the images the set will need new foam/re-upholstering, this will be a fairly straight forward job as the units are simple in form. The frame just needs cleaning and oiling (there is no structural damage present)..once done the piece will look stunning.

The group can be purchased as is for £1295, please enquire if you would like re-upholstery/restoration quotes using your own material/colour scheme.

name: Vintage flying saucer desk lamp by M.G.Wheeler of Connecticut USA circa 1950's

 Comprising : A square steel base with a brass arm that turns 360o on the base, supporting a louvered aluminium shade, all finished in a soft satin dove grey. 

Re-wired ready for use with new earthed lampholder. in-line switch, cable and plug. Stands 36cm (14 1/4") H, base is 24cm (93/8") Sq, shade is 30cm (11 3/4") D. A fabulous  space age design in excellent condition.

name: Pair of vintage Ernest Race stools designed circa 1950s for Race furniture (GB)
description:
Pair of vintage Ernest Race stools designed circa 1950s for Race furniture (GB).

Rare pair of plywood and steel bar/kitchen stools designed by Race in the early 1950's.

The laminated curved plywood seat above tri-form metal base with rubber boot feet. These are completely original, the seats were originally yellow, but appear to have been painted over in yellow during their lives. The metal bases would have originally been powder coated in either gloss white or black, sadly the paint has worn away over time leaving the metal exposed.

I would imagine these would be fairly easy to restore ie the bases can be primed and re-painted, and the seats stripped and again re-painted.
I'm not sure which way to go, either keeping them as original as possible or restoring them.

I have included an image taken from a Bonhams Auction catalogue dated 28th March 2000 to prove provenance as this is a rare and little known design.

Measurements : The stools measures 27 inches high and the seat is 13 inches by 10 inches.

name: Vintage Eames EA 115 Aluminium Group Lounge chair for Herman Miller C1958

This is an early original example finished in white Naugahyde with black nylon coated arms and a polished aluminium frame on a four prong swivel base with white nylon glides.

Condition : overall I would say very good, the frame could do with a re-polish as its dull and speckled in places but no cracks or repairs present (all hardware is intact). The nylon coated arms are very good with minimal loss. The white Naugahide seat is all intact, there are a couple of nicks and as always the corners are scrapped/worn etc. The seat itself is generally very clean, but there are some marks present commensurate with its age which may clean out. The base is fine and all the glides are present. The swivel mechanism works perfectly with no play at all in the bearings etc. The chair has the Herman Miller embossed mark to the underside.

Summary : overall this in my opinion is a nice early example, in a rare colour/material combination, showing minimal wear and tear considering its getting on for 50 years of age.

name: Vintage Poul Kjaerholm PK 61 slate & steel coffee table designed c1955 Denmark
description:
Vintage Poul Kjaerholm PK 61 slate & steel coffee table designed c1955 Denmark.

For sale we have a Poul Kjaerholm 'PK 61' slate and steel low occasional table. Kjaerholm first designed this model in 1955 and it was produced by the Danish company E.Kold.Christensen, production moved to Fritz Hansen (Denmark) in 1982.

Although this piece has a lovely age and patina to both the steel and slate, I cannot find the E.Kold. Christensen mark to the frame. Therefore I estimate it to be a Fritz Hansen version produced circa 1982.

Provenance : This piece along with other interesting period items ( set of 'PK 71' tables (marked E.Kold sold) Eames Shell chair, Hans Wegner sofa-bed, Bertoia chair) that are offered for sale came from the deceased estate of the British 'Brutalist' architect Rodney Gordon, who is famous for the Michael Faraday Memorial in the center of the Elephant & Castle roundabout.
He was also part of the architectural practice who designed the Trinity Centre, Gateshead, which became known to a wider audience as the carpark from whose roof mobster Jack Carter (Michael Caine) threw the corrupt councillor Cliff Brumby (Bryan Mosley) in the 1971 cult film Get Carter. Loved and loathed, but never unnoticed, Gordon's audacious designs marked him out as a seminal figure in English brutalist architecture.

Condition : the satin brushed stainless steel frame is structurally excellent, there are no breaks or re-welds. Unfortunately the finish on the steel has over time corroded and pitted in places. This is mainly confined to the top frame section which the slate sits on (so cannot be seen) and on all four of the frame uprights (see images). The original machine head screws are all present and correct. The slate top is original (not a replacement) it has a few areas of wear to the edges the largest being approx 10cm x 3 cm (see images) again no cracks or repairs present, shows a nice patina and originality.

Measurements : 80 cm x 80 cm (top) x 32 cm in height

These early examples are quite hard to find and offer character and charm, along with the provenance I think this piece is highly desirable and a good investment for the future. E.Kold examples sell for between £2-5k, to buy new from Fritz Hansen with the slate top will cost between 3-4000 Euro. Ive seen a new one and the slate offered is nowhere near as nice as on this one.

Its a difficult one to price right, so I'm offering it on a buy it now price of £995 or best offer.

Pick up only from our home address in London SE19 Crystal Palace area, please note it is extremely heavy and will require two people to lift it. You are welcome to arrange a viewing before buying, message me on 07940458890 (Gary)

Any questions or additional images please do hesitate to contact me at dad-design@hotmail.co.uk
